update.description:
The goal of this pull request is to add the ability to activated/deactivate plugins without needing to remove them form the plugins folder.

This is achieved by a simple modification to the `BLACS.plugins` module. It now check if a plugin is activated in the labconfig or not before adding it to the `modules` dict. The default setting for new plugins is active as I suspect new plugin will be added on purpose rather than accidentally.

To make the state of plugins user editable it is stored in the Labconfig file in a newly created section `BLACS/plugins`. 

This pull request should be inline with the result of the discussion that was held over at [Pull requests #9](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/pull-requests/9/delete-repeated-shots-functionality/diff).
update.title: Plugin Management

content.raw:
I thought about this some more I think there is not much use in arguing about this detail. 

I'll just hardcode a list of defaults.
content.html:
I thought about this some more I think there is not much use in arguing about this detail.

I'll just hardcode a list of defaults.

content.raw:
If we do that labs that have some custom plugins might be surprised to why they are gone\(as in disabled gone not deleted gone\) all of the sudden when updating.   
 It is a small thing to turn them back on but might cause some confusion that we could prevent by enabling every plugin present on first run after these changes.

I can not see a case where this would lead to undesired outcome. If the first run is with a fresh install that should just be the default plugins anyway and preexisting installs will keep all currently active plugins active.

Edit: I'm assuming that all plugins in the main repo will stay compatible with one another and that we only include stable plugins in the main repo
content.html:
If we do that labs that have some custom plugins might be surprised to why they are gone(as in disabled gone not deleted gone) all of the sudden when updating.
It is a small thing to turn them back on but might cause some confusion that we could prevent by enabling every plugin present on first run after these changes.

I can not see a case where this would lead to undesired outcome. If the first run is with a fresh install that should just be the default plugins anyway and preexisting installs will keep all currently active plugins active.

Edit: I'm assuming that all plugins in the main repo will stay compatible with one another and that we only include stable plugins in the main repo

content.raw:
Why not hard-code a list of "default enabled" plugins, and anything not on the list defaults to disabled?

That way we can change the list over time (such as when an experimental feature reaches stability) rather than basing it on the current set of plugins that happen to be there.
content.html:
Why not hard-code a list of "default enabled" plugins, and anything not on the list defaults to disabled?

That way we can change the list over time (such as when an experimental feature reaches stability) rather than basing it on the current set of plugins that happen to be there.

content.raw:
How about instead of hardcoding the standart Plugins we do the following to not break existent plugin architectures:

If there is no ‘BLACS/plugins‘ section initialize it and set the default plugin state to True. This ensures that BLACS behaves the same before and after this change.

if the ‘BLACS/Plugins‘ section exisists set default to False.

Long story short: First run everything will be enabled all other runs new plugins will be disabled
content.html:
How about instead of hardcoding the standart Plugins we do the following to not break existent plugin architectures:

If there is no ‘BLACS/plugins‘ section initialize it and set the default plugin state to True. This ensures that BLACS behaves the same before and after this change.

if the ‘BLACS/Plugins‘ section exisists set default to False.

Long story short: First run everything will be enabled all other runs new plugins will be disabled

content.raw:
Looking good!

I can't decide if we should enable plugins by default or not. Right now, I'd lean towards not enabling by default so that we can merge in random plugins that people have without it risking breaking other peoples systems. In this case we would only import the plugins that are enabled, thus giving the user an easy way to turn off plugins that are broken \(e.g. code with a syntax error\).

On the other hand, in the long term, we're likely to have separate repositories for plugins, and so in that case plugins would be deliberately added \(and thus should be enabled by default\). Enabling by default also solves the issue of having to write in a special case for enabling the existing plugins that are reasonably core to BLACS \(at least when running as a primary control system\).

‌

I think I'm leaning towards the first option, which would mean:

* plugins disabled by default
* plugin code only imported if enabled
* Hard code in enabling certain plugins if they don't exist in the labconfig \(e.g. all existing plugins\)

But, I'm not 100% certain I welcome discussion on the best way forward!
content.html:
Looking good!

I can't decide if we should enable plugins by default or not. Right now, I'd lean towards not enabling by default so that we can merge in random plugins that people have without it risking breaking other peoples systems. In this case we would only import the plugins that are enabled, thus giving the user an easy way to turn off plugins that are broken (e.g. code with a syntax error).

On the other hand, in the long term, we're likely to have separate repositories for plugins, and so in that case plugins would be deliberately added (and thus should be enabled by default). Enabling by default also solves the issue of having to write in a special case for enabling the existing plugins that are reasonably core to BLACS (at least when running as a primary control system).

‌

I think I'm leaning towards the first option, which would mean:

  • plugins disabled by default
  • plugin code only imported if enabled
  • Hard code in enabling certain plugins if they don't exist in the labconfig (e.g. all existing plugins)

But, I'm not 100% certain I welcome discussion on the best way forward!

To make the state of plugins user editable it is stored in the Labconfig file in a newly created section `BLACS/plugins`.
